page.title: 07COASTAL WALK TO CRAIL
page.content: This well marked, 11 mile coastal walk starts on the outskirts of St. Andrews, where one climbs to the top of Kinkell Braes. This cliff-top position has a wonderful view of St. Andrews . The abundant gorse, blackthorn and hawthorn are ideal habitats for small birds-finches and tits. The cliffs also house a variety of sea-birds, gulls,terns and oyster catchers. Further along is the Maiden Rock, an isolated pillar which was once part of the mainland. The cliffside is thickly covered in gorse and bracken, thinning to grass. The shore itself is covered in a variety of seaweeds ranging from oar weeds to bladder wrack. Kinkell Cave and Ness are passed before reaching the Rock and Spindle. Lapwing and curlews, ferns and mosses are all present at Kittocks Den.
